#Text=Elizabeth Polly

#Text=Elizabeth Polly ( died 1867 ) was a hospital matron at Fort Hays , Kansas , during the cholera outbreak of 1867 and died of the disease , and it is said that her ghost is still seen walking the area .
#Text=History
#Text=She was the young wife of Ephriam Polly , the hospital steward , or male nurse , during the cholera epidemic at Fort Hays in 1867 .
#Text=Elizabeth was the hospital matron who helped sick and dying soldiers deal with what were , for many , the final hours of their lives .
#Text=In the evening she would often walk to the hill south of the fort , now known as Sentinel Hill , where she is said to have found some comfort and spiritual healing .
#Text=When it was apparent that she had contracted the disease herself , she pleaded with her husband to bury her on top of the hill
#Text=and she was indeed buried on the hill , though not at the top .
#Text=According to the legend , her gravesite was marked with four heavy limestone posts .
#Text=These posts were stolen by thieves in the early days of Hays , Kansas .
#Text=The legend claims that tragedy found each of the thieves in the hours after the theft : one felled in a gunfight , two killed in a carriage accident , and the other hit by a train .
#Text=Sadly , due to the thefts , her exact gravesite has long been lost .
#Text=Some contend that the grave found at the base of the hill was not Polly 's , being instead that of a Mexican cattleman , based on the marker 's Spanish inscription .

#Text=In fact the " Lonely Grave , " as it is called , may not be an actual burial site at all , as no remains were found in attempts to fulfill Miss Polly 's wishes by moving her to the top of the hill .
#Text=The actual Sentinel Hill is completely made of bedrock , making it a highly unlikely burial ground .
#Text=Multiple attempts to locate her exact burial site have been made , and surprisingly , multiple bodies have been exhumed , but none was conclusively shown to be that of Elizabeth Polly .
#Text=Blue Light Lady
#Text=To most people who live in Hays , she is known as the " Blue Light Lady . "
#Text=Her spirit is said to still walk the hill looking to comfort her soldiers .
#Text=Many people have made attempts to witness her spirit firsthand .
#Text=Some have claimed that she has appeared wearing a blue , prairie-style dress and bonnet , while others claim that she is a misty blue light .

#Text=Other people have claimed that while waiting at the top of the hill for Elizabeth 's spirit to arrive , footsteps have been heard walking up the hill and suddenly disappearing at the top , yet nobody was to be found around the hill .
#Text=One specific event was reported in 1950 when a police officer radioed a report to dispatch saying that he had just hit a woman dressed in blue not far from the hill .
#Text=He then quickly exited his car and searched for a body .
#Text=None was ever found .
#Text=Memorials
#Text=Today , there is a monument to her on the top of Sentinel Hill , put there in 1967 .
#Text=A park dedicated to her was established in Hays in 1982 , [ 1 ] and it includes an Elizabeth Polly statue .
